metadata.synopsis: Brought to the White House to receive a Congressional Gold Medal from President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Broadway legend George M. Cohan (James Cagney) reflects on his life. Flashbacks trace Cohan's rise, from a childhood performing in his family's vaudeville act to his early days as a struggling Tin Pan Alley songwriter to his overwhelming success as an actor, writer, director and producer known for patriotic songs like "Yankee Doodle Dandy," "You're a Grand Old Flag" and "Over There."

reviews: Primarily a splashy exhibition of Cohan's most popular stories and lyrics and music (upbeat yet jingoistic arrangements).
It is an ideal attraction for every American theater, every American theaterman, and every theater-goer in America.
It's not the movie of a great man; it's the movie of a great idea: Democracy. [Full Review in Spanish]
Patriotic '40s classic charms, but some dated behaviors.
Maybe the best-case scenario for what happens when a film biopic does everything right.
Flag waving, toe tapping, GREAT James Cagney performance as Broadway's George M. Cohan.
A rousing, old-fashioned biopic of patriotic showman George M. Cohan, played with energy and gusto by Jimmy Cagney in his only Oscar-winning performance.
It delivers its red-white-and-blue patriotism to you by the exuberant bushel, but this grand old film reminds us that there was a time when patriotism was more heartfelt than bullying and jingoistic.
James Cagney played George M. Cohan with great vigor and won his only Oscar for that brilliant performance.
...Cagney's picture through and through. He imbues every scene with the kind of electricity only a handful of screen stars have ever managed.
A timeless treasure that will never fade. Cagney is great; Huston unforgetable. A wonderful slice of Americana.
